Step 4: Output the summarized chunk (a) Findings.--Congress has authorized 18 commemorative coin programs since 1984, but there are more worthy causes than can be honored. The pace of commemorative coin legislation has surpassed what the numismatic community can handle, so a policy to control it is needed.
(b) Declaration.--It is recommended that committees in the House and Senate should not consider legislation for more than 2 commemorative coin programs. SEC. 302. REPORTS BY RECIPIENTS OF COMMEMORATIVE COIN SURCHARGES. Each person receiving surcharge proceeds from commemorative coin sales must submit quarterly financial reports detailing expenditures to the Director of the United States Mint and the Comptroller General of the United States. Quarterly reports must include the proportion of surcharges to total revenue, percentage of revenue spent on administrative expenses, and are due 30 days after the end of each calendar quarter. Final reports on expenditures from surcharge proceeds must be submitted by recipients of commemorative coin surcharges. The recipient of commemorative coin surcharges must submit final reports on expenditures, including information described in subsection (a)(2), within 1 year of the last day of coin sales. The Comptroller General must provide a financial statement to Congress on the use of surcharges from commemorative coin sales within 1 year of the end of sales. The "Bicentennial of the United States Capitol Commemorative Coin Act" is the short title for this legislation. Specifications for the coins are outlined in section 402. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue up to 500,000 one-dollar silver coins, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and composed of 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins must be emblematic of the bicentennial of the United States Capitol, with inscriptions including the year "1994" and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". These coins are legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. All coins minted under this title shall be considered numismatic items as per section 5132(a)(1) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 403. The Secretary must obtain silver for minting coins from designated stockpiles. SEC. 404. The coin design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with specific officials. SEC. 405. Details the issuance of coins. SEC. 405. Issuance of one-dollar coins in uncirculated and proof qualities from May 1, 1994, to April 30, 1995. Contracts for promotion require approval by the United States Capitol Preservation Commission. SEC. 406. Sale of coins. SEC. 406. SALE OF COINS. The Secretary will sell coins at face value plus design and issuance costs. Bulk sales will have a discount, and prepaid orders will also receive a discount. A surcharge of $15 per coin will be included in all sales. SEC. 407. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 407. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the Government for minting and issuing coins. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantee for payment. SEC. 408. USE OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to Capitol Preservation Fund for the Commission. SEC. 409. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. SEC. 409. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this title, except for equal employment opportunity laws.
